nodes.text: Machine learning algorithms can be used to predict stock market values and help investors make better buy/sell decisions
A systematic literature review (SLR) was conducted to summarize prior research on machine learning for stock market prediction
Predicting stock market values is necessary because accurate forecasts help investors increase profit and avoid losses
Commonly used machine learning algorithms for stock prediction include linear regression, neural networks, genetic algorithms, support vector machines, k-nearest neighbor, and random forest

Key attributes and factors used as inputs for prediction models include market history, news/events, general public mood (social media), commodity prices, interest rate, foreign exchange, oil/gold/silver rates, and macroeconomic indicators
Combining event knowledge or news-derived event information with machine learning models, especially neural networks, improves prediction accuracy
Prediction accuracy depends on choice of algorithm, attribute selection, and size/quality of training data

SLR search process: initial corpus approx 550 papers from major digital libraries, filtered by title then abstract then full text yielding 45 included papers; inclusion required English and full availability; quality assessed by author contribution analysis
Multiple studies report SVM performs well for stock movement prediction and often outperforms other classifiers in comparative evaluations
Random forest and other ensemble classifiers have been used; reported accuracies vary across studies (examples: random forest 83% reported in one study, 64% in another)
Empirical analyses indicate event information (extracted from news) and social media features are correlated with stock price changes and are useful predictive inputs
Studies report moderate predictive accuracies (examples: multi-classifier study 65% accuracy); accuracy can be improved with more effective attributes and larger training datasets
Combining event knowledge with other attributes increased prediction accuracy by about five percent in reported experiments and is recommended by several researchers
The reviewed literature concludes that machine learning offers useful predictive tools for investors but performance is variable and depends on data, features, and algorithm choice
